name: Asteroid Collision
title: Asteroid Collision
content:
We are given an array asteroids of integers representing asteroids in a row. The indices of the asteriod in the array represent their relative position in space.

For each asteroid, the absolute value represents its size, and the sign represents its direction (positive meaning right, negative meaning left). Each asteroid moves at the same speed.

Find out the state of the asteroids after all collisions. If two asteroids meet, the smaller one will explode. If both are the same size, both will explode. Two asteroids moving in the same direction will never meet.

 

Example 1:

Input: asteroids = [5,10,-5]
Output: [5,10]
Explanation: The 10 and -5 collide resulting in 10. The 5 and 10 never collide.

Example 2:

Input: asteroids = [8,-8]
Output: []
Explanation: The 8 and -8 collide exploding each other.

Example 3:

Input: asteroids = [10,2,-5]
Output: [10]
Explanation: The 2 and -5 collide resulting in -5. The 10 and -5 collide resulting in 10.

 

Constraints:

  • 2 <= asteroids.length <= 104
  • -1000 <= asteroids[i] <= 1000
  • asteroids[i] != 0

discussion_posts.name: superogatory
discussion_posts.content:
Draw a row and place asteroids in that row in the same order you see them in your input. For example with [-2,-1,1,2], draw two lines on a piece of paper or whiteboard or whatever medium works best for you, and place asteroids from left to right in the same order as the input.

------------------------------------------
-2(<-)     -1(<-)     1(->)     2(->)
------------------------------------------

Jot down the direction of each asteroid as well. For example, right above your negative 2, draw a left arrow. Right above your positive 1, draw a right arrow. Assuming that asteroids moving in the same direction never meet, and thus never explode. Do any asteroids meet in this case? Well, no. -2 moves left, -1 moves left, 1 moves right, 2 moves right. None meet, none explode.

Try this with [1,-2,10,5]
------------------------------------------
1(->)     -2(<-)     10(->)     5(->)
------------------------------------------

Wait, hang on a second, 1 and -2 are destined to collide. Take note of their directions. If element at index i is moving right, and element at index i + 1 is moving left, NOW we can have a collision. Examine the case where element at index i is moving left, and element at index i + 1 is moving right, will they collide? Don't know? Draw it!

------------------------------------------
-1(<-)     2(->)     10(->)     5(->)
------------------------------------------

So if element at index i is moving left and element at index i + 1 is moving right, they will not collide. Thus, collisions can ONLY occur if the element at index i (previous asteroid) is moving right and the element at index i + 1 (current asteroid) is moving left.

What does it mean for an element/asteroid to be moving left or right? That means that the asteroid is negative or positive, respectively. Thus we can revise our previous hypothesis, collisions can occur ONLY if the element at index i is positive and the element at index i + 1 is negative.

Needless to say, in order for a collision to occur we need to be able to examine two asteroids.

We can use a stack (or a vector/list/array), up to you really, to solve this problem. Where you place elements onto the stack one by one, the moment we encounter an element that is less than 0 then we have "collision potential", because an element before the one we just found, if it be positive, indicates a collision. And if we have multiple right moving asteroids (positive value) on the stack, then we can have multiple collisions with current asteroid we are looking at. We can extend this idea to flesh out a proper solution where we keep placing elements onto the stack until we encounter an asteroid that is left-moving, as this kind of asteroid could cause a collision with the one(s) before it that is/are right-moving. 

To clarify:
For each asteroid, check if it is moving to the left (negative) and if the stack is not empty.

If the current asteroid is moving left (negative) and there are right-moving (positive) asteroids on the stack, we have a potential collision scenario.
Compare the absolute values of the asteroids on the stack with the current asteroid to determine the outcome of the collision.

If the absolute value of the current asteroid is greater, it will destroy the smaller asteroid(s) on the stack. Remove the smaller asteroid(s) from the stack.

If the absolute value of the current asteroid is smaller, it will be destroyed. Skip pushing it onto the stack.

If the absolute values are equal, both asteroids will be destroyed. Remove the top asteroid from the stack.

discussion_posts.name: bparanj
discussion_posts.content:
The Asteroid Collision problem can be considered a variation of the classic Balancing Symbols problem, although it might not be immediately apparent.

The Balancing Symbols problem is a classic problem where you have a sequence of symbols, such as parentheses, and you want to determine if they are "balanced". That is, for every opening symbol, there should be a corresponding closing symbol. One common way to solve this problem is by using a stack data structure.

In the case of the Asteroid Collision problem, the "opening" and "closing" symbols are replaced by positive and negative integers respectively, with positive integers moving right and negative integers moving left. We can imagine the problem as trying to determine if the movements of the asteroids are "balanced", similar to the parentheses in the Balancing Symbols problem. That is, for every right-moving asteroid, is there a corresponding left-moving asteroid that would collide with it, and vice versa.

Therefore, the stack can be used in a similar way: When we encounter a right-moving asteroid (positive integer), we push it into the stack. When we encounter a left-moving asteroid (negative integer), we compare it with the top of the stack. If the left-moving asteroid is larger, we pop the right-moving asteroid from the stack (analogous to matching and removing a pair of opening and closing symbols), and continue the process until the stack is empty or the top of the stack is a left-moving asteroid.

Thus, while the problems are different in their specific details, they share a common structure that allows us to apply similar problem-solving strategies. It's this underlying structure that allows us to identify the Asteroid Collision problem as a variation of the Balancing Symbols problem.
